content.description: The THIN flake on the right side of the wall with Annihilator. Start on some fun fist jams then use the flake as a layback up to the top. Takes gear nicely at the bottom but no way would the rock not break toward the top if you fell on a cam. There is a bolt at the top you can set a toprope off and a hangerless bolt right next to it you can throw a nut onto for a little extra piece of mind.
content.protection: Fist size, but really you should just TR or solo.
content.location: On the right side of the Annihilator wall, just on the other side of the gully of Super Squeeze.

content.description: On the west end of Queen. Hop onto the ledge then climb the thin crack in the middle of what is basically two boulders.
content.location: On the far right side of Queen

content.description: Climb a short section of offwidth, using face holds outside it to reach a horizontal break. From here, move up and right into the flake filled chimney. Climb this until you hit a horizontal crack. Traverse left, grab a dubious looking knob/flake (last chance for pro), then pull out of the overhang and onto the slab above.
content.protection: Single rack. #5 if you aren't comfortable bouldering the wide crack start. Can be TR'd off a few medium size cams on top, or (awkwardly) off two bolts.
content.location: The offwidth crack that widens to a chimney, located just to the right of Shoulder Crack.

content.description: The huge flake that seems to be falling off of the boulder that Hermes is on. Do your best at offwidth climbing at the bottom then work your feet up and use the flake as a huge sidepull. The gear is just about non existent without some huge stuff and even then, they may seem a little hard to trust on the flake. It is really easy to set a bomber gear anchor at the top with gear up to a #4 and TR the sucker too. If you really want to have some fun try to stay in the crack the whole time, probably bumps the grade to 10+.
content.protection: An unfortunate lack of it, but think big! Gear anchor at the top goes up to #4.
content.location: The left side of the boulder with Hermes, it is a pretty prominent and obvious feature. Just left of the "canyon" you can use to get to the top.

content.description:
A hard start, and sustained movement up to the ledge. Once on the ledge, climb the beautiful, easy patina on the SE rounded arete. Originally listed as a 5.8 in the Bishop guide, this is most certainly either the worst sandbag, or some key holds have broken, as evidenced by the discolored rock in a few key places where a face hold would be great.

Descent:

Walk off right.
content.protection: Gear to BD#1, and a double length sling to wrap around a chicken head on the easy upper face. Build an anchor, or use any of the multitude of anchor bolts up top if they look good to you.
content.location: On the NE corner of the Queen, climb the short, thin right facing corner just below and left of the big platform boulders.

content.description: The prominent crack starting off of the sandy ledge on the middle boulder. Nothing to strenuous and pretty good hands toward the top.
content.location: Between the Fault and Buck Fever

content.description: A great first trad lead for somebody or a fun warmup for those who already know what they are doing. This climb goes up the hand to fist sized crack on the right side of the short wall with three prominent cracks (hence the name). Start off of the boulder or down in the pit and move over both holds outside the crack, and the crack itself. Smooth and easy, but nothing to get too excited about.
content.location: On the short wall near the east most top out gully it is the prominent crack on the right side.

content.description:
Climb the bolted east face/arete. First bolt is kind of high. Can reach around from the boulder ledge and clip the first bolt in lieu of stick clipping.

Descent:

Walk off right.
content.protection: 2 bolts to one single cold shut. Options for supplemental gear anchor on top of ledge.
content.location: East side of the Queen North face, on the arete. Start on the dirt down below the big boulder.

content.description: The face climb just the the right of Dreamweaver. Set a TR off of a gear anchor on Dreamweaver then work your way through the shenanigans of the face/slab sequence and finish the last few feet the same as Dreamweaver. According to the book, the right arete is off. Feel free to use it though, just knocks the grade down to about 9+.
content.protection: TR off of the top of Dreamweaver
content.location: Just right of the Dreamweaver crack.

content.description: The flared chimeny that The Fault and Hermes starts out of. Instead of escaping out, go straight for it and move over fist jams that slowly become much bigger, and much more flared.
content.protection: Up to 8" or top rope off of the anchors on top of The Fault.

content.description: A really fun hand to fist sized crack with some extras on the outside to help you out. This climb is the leftmost of the three climbs on the north facing wall near the top out gully. Well worth doing despite it's unimposing nature.
content.location: The leftmost obvious crack of the three on the north facing wall near the eastern most top out gully.

content.description: Start in the same corner as The Fault but then bust left over a few thin moves and into a low angle crack to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack with some small stuff, TR

content.description: Climb up the short slab to a horizontal break, then up the finger crack to the set of double hand cracks above.
content.protection: Standard rack. Anchor at top, bring long slings.
content.location: First route after dropping down to the lower bench of the Queen. Right around the corner from the wide crack / dihedral of Mike's Butt Cheeks.

content.description: Start just left of Dreamweaver and work your way up some super slaby rock that technically could be called a finger crack, but is all friction off of the bottom. Work up into the steeper part of the face and move through some fun layback sequences to the deceptively hard top, finishing left of Dreamweaver. Like for morning blues the arete near this climb is technically off according to the book, and again feel free to use it just know it's not gonna be 11d if you do. Both Morning Blues and Feelings I only gave one start due to their kind of contrived nature.
content.protection: TR off of Dreamweaver gear anchor

content.description: Start at the bottom of the flared chimney and then follow the slopey seam up out and right, this is definitely the crux but very fun. Continue up the crack around the corner to the top.
A short but very fun crack that arches up and right through the middle of a beautiful red face. Just begging to be climbed this route has good movement and takes even better gear. Walk off the back.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3". Two bolts anchor (no chains) at the top of this route.
content.location: Right up the middle of the north facing wall just left of the Annihilator wall.

content.description: Hop up on the ledge and climb the fatter hand/fist size crack just to the left of Wot and right of the the practice chimney.
Right between the Left Side and the Right Side, obviously, this fist to offwidth sized crack can be done using the holds on the outside or you can challenge yourself by using only the crack.
content.location: Right in the middle of the north facing wall next to the east most top out gully

content.description: A very picturesque thin crack working right of the middle of the large overhanging prow. Very bouldery and hard crux pulling through the steep section at the bottom. Once you are through the crux keep working up the thin overhanging crack, and have fun!
content.location: Right up the middle of the prow you see and say "man I wanna climb that!"
